docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of cafeteria and other food-service workers rallied in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday afternoon for higher wages and improved benefits as part of an ongoing battle between the Aramark Corporation and the union Unite Here, which represents about 20,000 Aramark employees, including about 4,000 in the New York region.

headline.main: Cafeteria Workers Protest on Wall Street

docs.abstract: At the urging of the union Unite Here, workers for Aramark, a giant food-services company, protested outside the offices of several Wall Street financial companies where union members serve in the cafeterias.
docs.snippet: At the urging of the union Unite Here, workers for Aramark, a giant food-services company, protested outside the offices of several Wall Street financial companies where union members serve in the cafeterias.

docs.lead_paragraph: A trio of firms is seeking to promote a concept called cloud computing, in which companies keep their corporate data, confidential and otherwise, online.
docs.snippet: A trio of firms is seeking to promote a concept called cloud computing, in which companies keep their corporate data, confidential and otherwise, online.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victories over Barack Obama in Ohio and Texas gave her a chance to soldier on. John McCain claimed the G.O.P. nomination.

headline.main: Big Wins for Clinton in Texas and Ohio; McCain Clinches Race as Foe Concedes
headline.sub: Obama Still Holds Lead in Delegates
headline.print_headline: Texas and Ohio to Clinton; McCain Is In as Choice for the G.O.P.

docs.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victories over Barack Obama in Ohio and Texas gave her a chance to soldier on. John McCain claimed the G.O.P. nomination.

byline.contributor: Marjorie Connelly and Megan Thee contributed reporting from New York, and John M. Broder from Columbus, Ohio.

docs.lead_paragraph: When the latest monthly employment report comes out this week, politicians will be quick to point out that joblessness remains low by historical standards, but the figures can be misleading.
docs.snippet: When the latest monthly employment report comes out this week, politicians will be quick to point out that joblessness remains low by historical standards, but the figures can be misleading.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton broke her streak of losses to Barack Obama, allowing her to soldier on in the Democratic presidential nomination race.

headline.main: Clinton Says Her Campaign Has ‘Turned a Corner’
headline.sub: Big Victories in Texas and Ohio
headline.print_headline: Obama Still Holds Lead in Delegates

docs.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton broke her streak of losses to Barack Obama, allowing her to soldier on in the Democratic presidential nomination race.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite pleas from doctors, immigration law is preventing the sister of a legal permanent resident, whose wife recently died after giving birth, permission to visit to help care for the baby.

headline.main: Mourning Resonates From Staten Island to Sri Lanka
headline.sub: Visa Denial Prevents Sister From Coming to Help Out ;
headline.print_headline: Mourning Resonates From Staten Island to Sri Lanka

docs.snippet: Despite pleas from doctors, immigration law is preventing the sister of a legal permanent resident, whose wife recently died after giving birth, permission to visit to help care for the baby.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Times's Randy Kennedy and Andrew Jacobs have been embedded in Texas and Ohio over the past weeks, writing about the tight primary races in those states. We invited them to compare notes.

headline.main: On the Ground: The View From Texas and Ohio

docs.abstract: Randy Kennedy and Andrew Jacobs report from Texas and Ohio.
docs.snippet: Randy Kennedy and Andrew Jacobs report from Texas and Ohio.

byline.original: By JAYSON K. JONES AND ANA C. ROSADO

docs.lead_paragraph: In Cambridge, Ohio, we sat down with one of our voters in the Open Caucus roundtable to talk about Tuesday's primary and the issues on the minds of Ohioans. Stephen Heine, 62, a moderate Republican, has decided to support Senator John McCain, although he said he had favored former Senator Fred Thompson before he dropped out of the race.
docs.abstract: Stephen Heine, an Ohio resident and a member of The Caucus's virtual round table of voters, talks about the 2008 election.
docs.snippet: Stephen Heine, an Ohio resident and a member of The Caucus's virtual round table of voters, talks about the 2008 election.
